citations.narrative:
The 5 cats maintained by the facility do not have official identification as required by the Animal Welfare Act. Not having
proper identification can cause misidentification of animals on inspections, veterinary care documentation, acquisition,
and disposition records. The Licensee must ensure that an official USDA sequentially numbered tag is placed on the
animals with a collar or kept on the door of the animals' cage or run, or an approved tattoo or microchip is used to
positively identify the animals. If tags are maintained on the enclosure (rather than a collar) then the licensee must have a
record book containing each animal’s tag number, a written description of each animal, and a clear photograph of each
animal. Each tag must contain the letters “USDA”, the certificate number identifying the state as well as the facility, and a
number identifying the animal. A duplicate tag must also accompany each cat whenever it leaves the premise. Correct by
November 24th 2023.

Five kittens, two 4 months old, two 6 weeks old and one 8 weeks old, were housed outdoors in an enclosure made from a
stall within a wooden barn. The front of the enclosure was made of a wire mesh and small gaps could be seen between
the wooden slats of the back wall of the enclosure. As is, the enclosure did not protect the cats from the cold and a shelter
was not provided. At the time of inspection, the temperature within the enclosure was 40° F and the kittens were huddled
together in a small bed. Such low temperatures can lead to hypothermia, diseases or discomfort to such young animals.
The facility must provide the kittens with adequate shelter from the cold. Such shelter must contain clean, dry, bedding
material if the ambient temperature is below 50 °F. Additional clean, dry bedding is required when the temperature is 35
°F or lower. Correct by November 10th, 2023.

5 rabbits were housed outdoors in an enclosure with a wire mesh front and large gaps in the bottom of the back wall. The
enclosure as is does not provide protection from the cold and a shelter was not provided. At the time of inspection, the
environmental temperature was 40°F and per the weather channel the low for the day was 29°F. Three of the rabbits were
outside of the enclosure and huddled together on the floor. Low temperatures such as these could result in animal
disease or discomfort. Shelter must be provided for all rabbits kept outdoors when the atmospheric temperature falls
below 40°F. Correct by November 10th, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.50(c) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The 5 cats maintained by the facility do not have official identification as required by the Animal Welfare Act. Not having 
proper identification can cause misidentification of animals on inspections, veterinary care documentation, acquisition, 
and disposition records. The Licensee must ensure that an official USDA sequentially numbered tag is placed on the 
animals with a collar or kept on the door of the animals' cage or run, or an approved tattoo or microchip is used to 
positively identify the animals. If tags are maintained on the enclosure (rather than a collar) then the licensee must have a 
record book containing each animal’s tag number, a written description of each animal, and a clear photograph of each 
animal. Each tag must contain the letters “USDA”, the certificate number identifying the state as well as the facility, and a 
number identifying the animal. A duplicate tag must also accompany each cat whenever it leaves the premise. Correct by 
November 24th 2023. 
3.4(b)(4) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
Five kittens, two 4 months old, two 6 weeks old and one 8 weeks old, were housed outdoors in an enclosure made from a 
stall within a wooden barn. The front of the enclosure was made of a wire mesh and small gaps could be seen between 
the wooden slats of the back wall of the enclosure. As is, the enclosure did not protect the cats from the cold and a shelter 
was not provided. At the time of inspection, the temperature within the enclosure was 40° F and the kittens were huddled 
together in a small bed. Such low temperatures can lead to hypothermia, diseases or discomfort to such young animals. 
The facility must provide the kittens with adequate shelter from the cold. Such shelter must contain clean, dry, bedding 
material if the ambient temperature is below 50 °F. Additional clean, dry bedding is required when the temperature is 35 
°F or lower. Correct by November 10th, 2023. 
3.52(c) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
5 rabbits were housed outdoors in an enclosure with a wire mesh front and large gaps in the bottom of the back wall. The 
enclosure as is does not provide protection from the cold and a shelter was not provided. At the time of inspection, the 
environmental temperature was 40°F and per the weather channel the low for the day was 29°F. Three of the rabbits were 
outside of the enclosure and huddled together on the floor. Low temperatures such as these could result in animal

disease or discomfort. Shelter must be provided for all rabbits kept outdoors when the atmospheric temperature falls 
below 40°F. Correct by November 10th, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
 n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
